Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing festival wreath headdress with two lotus buds (or horns?) and the sun disc and horns. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. Red slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with dark red-brown core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar example from Naukratis that Gutch dated to between 150BC and 250AD (Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology NA644; Gutch 1899, pl. 12, no.190). Similar headdress on a late 2nd century BC Harpocrates in Dresden (Fischer 1994, no. 647), though this red slipped type may be later and from the Early Roman Period. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.075) (Phase 3)
